name: 12 Labours of Hercules
description: Accompany Hercules on a quest to rescue his wife, kidnapped by the evil Hades in 12 Labours of Hercules! You'll meet heroes from Ancient Greece as you vanquish beasts, repair roads and construct wonders in this stunning Time Management game!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: 1.6 GHz Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: 1024x768 resolution DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 300 MB available space Sound Card: On board

reviews.review_text: 12 Labours of Hercules  is a fun little resource and time management game by Jetdogs Studios which was designed for iOS and ported into PC due to its popularity later on. This first one in the series is fun, relaxing and a point on choice for a couple of easy achievements as the rest of the series. If you feel like sparing time for a series of automated actions to meet certain challenges and have a smile now and then, keep reading.  First and foremost, these games are vaguely based on the actual  12 Labours of Hercules , an epic poem written by Peisander in 600 BC, narrating the 12 years that legendary Greek hero spent in service to King Eurystheus to atone for killing his own family whence he was maddened by Hera. As you can see, these kiddy versions of the legend are not as gruesome as the actual tale. For the content of the game, there is little to no story. All we know is that Hades abducted Megara - Hercules' wife - for unknown reasons and we are to take her back by building a path between Hellas and the Underworld with the aid of our servants and some monster buddies of ours. The game - as the rest of its instalments - mostly consists of thrown around mythological figures and a most required happy ending.  As for the display, art is cartoonish and enjoyable; not the worst that I've encountered in these kind of casual games. Icons and animations are cute. Everything’s pretty much Disney-ish actually. Music is cute, but with this amount of repetition in each and every level you may prefer muting it down after some time.  As for the gameplay, you basically drive some servants to collect resources, build paths and activate certain encounters within a limited time while you and your monster 'buddies' overcome some challenges. Game mechanics are real simple and easy to master, and your abilities to buff certain conditions makes this a casual game with little strategic planning. The most you'd find to be challenging is the achievement to complete all levels on Gold Time. It is possible to finish all quests within 3-4 hours anyhow.  If you feel like taking a break from some serious business that you've been attending, this is the perfect game with little to no brain involvement. You mostly play it with your reaction rate. All these games do go for a decent sale most of the time, so you may prefer getting it in one of those times. Enjoy! 12 Labours of Hercules   is a casual time-puzzle game. Hades has kidnapped Megara, and it is up to Hercules, and especially his servant, to travel ancient Greece to save her.   Pros : While Hercules is taking a nap, you order his servant around in single-screen puzzles, where you must reach your objectives within a set time limit. The point is to optimize the order in which you pick the resources and accomplish tasks that consumes those same resources, tasks such as fixing the path or upgrading buildings that generate resources or supply additional servants. As you progress, you will get access to a few bonus powers, and gather allies such as the Medusa, the Pegasus, the Cyclops and the Cerberus, each of which can defeat enemies blocking your path or accomplish special tasks. The colorful map is overlayed with symbols of the game achievements you accomplished, and landmarks that gets build as you get gold rating at each levels.   Cons : The game is extremely easy, you'll rarely ever need to restart a level to get gold rating. Due to lack of randomization, it's unlikely you'll ever replay any levels except for the slightly less easy-to-get achievements. The story really is an excuse to give the world a setting.   Verdict : ★★★☆☆ - It's up to you  This game is basic, even for a casual game, and might be a bit more challenging for a much younger audience. But keeping in mind its price, I'd recommend it for children and achievement hunters, but anyone seeking any form of challenge in a puzzle should stay clear.  —————————————————————————   This was just my opinion.   If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated)  reviews .

A set of four equally nice, neatly made (in every aspect) time managers. Slightly diversified (with new game play features, bonuses and surprises) to make each game a bit different, while keeping enough in common with the previouse one(s), which shortens waste of time and nerve on mastering the next game, that's valuable. Repetative, yet it feels all right here, can't remember myself being driven into bore even once. I beat all four games 100% on expert difficulty and still wouldn't mind to see the fifth. Taken into account the fact that games like these are not my idea of fun (or they weren't at least))) - what better recommendation could i give to a game. If you are looking for a highly involving and entertaining, not all that hard yet challenging enough game - check this one. Probably you will be pleased even beyond your expectations. --------------- Серия из четырех одинаково отличных и очень качественно(во всех отношениях) сделанных игр- тайм менеджеров. Слегка отличающихся друг от друга (по набору игровых аспектов, бонусов и сюрпризов), ровно настолько чтобы не быть совсем однообразными, и при этом не вынуждать учиться играть заново, что несколько сокращает затраты времени и нервов на освоение каждой следующей игры, что порадовало. В принципе они достаточно однообразны, но здесь это не кажется недостатком, не помню ни разу чтобы это как то обломало интерес к игре. Полностью прошел все четыре на экспертной сложности и не отказался бы от пятой. С учетом того, что сами игры далеко не из списка моих предпочтений (по крайней мере не были))), вряд ли я придумаю способ высказаться об игре в еще более позитивном духе. В общем, если вы подыскиваете что-нибудь достаточно увлекательно-развлекательное, при этом не слишком сложное, но тем не менее бросающее определенный вызов вашим способностям в пределах разумных затрат времени и сил - то это как раз то что надо. Вполне возможно порадует даже сверх ожиданий.

Straightforward time manager with in a Greek mythological antiquity setting. You have workers for mundane tasks like collecting food, chopping woods, clearing paths, and have Hercules for bigger tasks like tossing boulders or buidling temples. Each task either yields food, wood. etc., requires a certain amount of those resources, or is some combination, e.g., requiring food and wood to mine gold, which is another main resource. The workers have to run back and forth to their little house which takes time, so the order in which you do the tasks matters. Not only is distance the workers have to run a factor, but how quickly you can upgrade your house to get another worker, or build a farm to generate food periodically, can also have a big impact.   All in all a solid time manager that is reasonably priced at $3. It is also available on iOS, but it is not clear whether this was a port to or from iOS since the release date (according to Metacritic) was Oct. 30, 2013 for PC, but April 23, 2014 for the iOS version. Regardless, this game stands on its on as a PC game, while it certainly would make a good touch-based game, since you are mainly just clicking the next task for workers/Hercules to perform, the game has enough depth and variation to retain one's interest.

Provides a few hours of brainless entertainment, good value for the price.  Pros:  + Crisp and vivid graphics + Catchy music and good sound design + User friendly controls + Easy minigames (even for one who sucks at action games) + Quite easy gameplay and achievements (Aside of one map, I got gold score for all of them for the first try. Damn that 3.8 map, I had to replay it 4-5 times :D)  Cons:  - The plot can de summed up by the damsel-in-distresss cliche - The gameplay quickly becomes monotone as is usual with this genre. From around thirdway through the player has to do some minimal strategic thinking before/during each map, but the gameplay is still mostly just mindless clicking on the next green circle. - The tutorial could be a bit more informative. I only realised after playing half the maps that the storage building actually increases output. (There isn't much time to try to decipher icon-based tooltips in the middle of the game.) Also even after finishing the game it's still not clear if the 'more resources' bonus speeds up the blue circles too or just the farm & workshop.

Pretty solid, really.

Very new to playing games? Like point and click games? Want something easy and non taxing to play? Did you answer Yes? Then this game is for you!   12 Labours of Hercules needs only one thing to play it - a mouse! [or, if like me, you have a touch screen laptop or tablet capable of launching the steam client, that will also work too]   The premise is simple, you are taken back to ancient Greece, and must help hercules complete his tasks to save the day! Achievements are easy to unlock, making this game ideal for the first time steam user or casual gamer. Every so often through out the game, you will find mini cut scene movies, and the odd boss battle, but these can be easily over come with a click of your mouse pad.   Pros *nice clear graphics *easy to play - no gamepad or keyboard pressing required *easy to follow format *suitable for any age group from 5 to 105 (no onscreen violence)   Cons *not suitable for those who like a challenge *more basic than your average rpg

TL;DNR = you can now play this game without having to connect to the internet first - but don't count on that remaining the case. Steam changes their minds about this stuff at will and you have no recourse because they already have your money. In the meantime - thank heaven for GOG.  I have recently discovered that you can now start and play this game not only in offline mode (Steam is NEVER really offline anymore and hasn't been for years) but even when there is no internet connection at all (which is the only way to force 'offline' mode in Steam to actually be offline. It is SO super annoying to start Steam in offline mode only to have it take 20 or 30 minutes to 'update' the steam client - which is what happens on slow internet connections).  So my objection to and disappointment with the game is assuaged, at least for as long as this remains true.  Sadly my son has recently discovered that he can no longer play the steam version of Civ IV in single player mode without an internet connection at startup, which has greatly reduced my interest in acquiring THAT game.   C'mon Steam, stop being such a jerk. There are a whole lot of us who don't have reliable (or sometimes ANY) internet access. Say, guys on oil rigs. People who live where there isn't cable. POOR people. People with crappy ISPs that go down all the time. We should be able to play our games even without going to the library to use the free wi-fi.  I am updating this review while weeding out my wishlist - mostly by removing all the games I can buy on GOG - because of nonsense like not being able to play when the internet is down or otherwise unavailable.  Original review follows:  This is a pretty typical time management game - except I recently discovered that it requires an internet connection. It will not start at all if you have Steam in Offline mode. If you bring Steam up in online mode and then turn off your connection, then you can start it, but it warns you that you will lose all your 'progress' - eg they are storing scores in the cloud.  Since I could care less about 'progress' per se, that's not really much of an issue for me. But not being able to play it in offline mode from the start IS a problem. I am frequently without internet and in need of a time killer. This is clearly not suitable unto the cause.  Now that I know, I looked for some hint of this in the game description and did not find it. I really object to being sold a game, any game, no matter how cheap, only to find out that there are restrictions on it that prevent me from playing it offline. This is why my GOG collection is so much larger (and older) than anything I have had on Steam to date. I expect it will likely continue to be the case.
